title: Energy Pulls Down Stocks --- U.S. crude posts steepest percentage decline since August; McDonald's rises
text:
Investors say that, overall, corporate earnings have reassured them that companies have been able to take issues like supply-chain problems, inflation and a slowdown in Chinese economic growth in stride.

Despite Wednesday's pullback, the S&P 500 remains on course for its biggest monthly advance since November.

"Investors got fairly gloomy in September, clearly against the backdrop of all sorts of macro concerns," said Paul O'Connor, head of the multiasset team at Janus Henderson Investors. "The broader story from results is that companies are managing these dynamics pretty well and also managing expectations fairly well."

The S&P 500 finished down 23.11 points, or 0.5%, at 4551.68, a day after the broad stocks gauge closed at record for the 57th time this year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average -- which also closed Tuesday at a record -- fell 266.19 points, or 0.7%, to 35490.69. The technology-focused Nasdaq Composite Index gave up early gains to finish up 0.12 point, or less than 0.1%, at 15235.84.

McDonald's shares rose $6.31, or 2.7%, to $242.73 after the fast-food chain said that higher prices had lifted its U.S. sales.

Coca-Cola gained $1.05, or 1.9%, to $55.52 after the beverage firm topped Wall Street forecasts for earnings and revenue.

Shares of Robinhood Markets dropped $4.13, or 10%, to $35.44 after the trading app recorded a 35% decline in revenue from the previous quarter, driven by lower volumes of crypto trading.

Meanwhile, energy stocks fell alongside the price of oil. The S&P 500 energy sector finished the day down 2.9%, posting the biggest decline of the broad index's 11 sectors. U.S. crude for December delivery lost $1.99, or 2.4%, to $82.66 a barrel, posting its steepest one-day percentage decline since mid-August.

Money managers still have worries, ranging from the fate of President Biden's infrastructure and social-spending plans to the potential unwind of Federal Reserve stimulus measures that have boosted markets since early 2020.

In the latest sign the economy slowed in the third quarter, data out Wednesday showed durable-goods orders fell 0.4% in September from August.

Elsewhere, the Stoxx Europe 600 fell 0.4%, pulling back from its second-highest close on record.

Bank shares retreated, with Deutsche Bank sliding 6.9% after the German lender reported a fall in investment-banking revenue. Shares of resource and oil-and-gas companies also lost ground.

In the cryptocurrency market, bitcoin fell 5% to $58,957.14 at 5 p.m. New York time. Ether lost 6.5% to $3,984.14 and dogecoin fell 9.4% to 24.1 cents.

In currency markets, the dollar finished U.S. trading day lower against the euro at $1.1603, higher against the British pound at $1.3740 and lower against the Japanese yen at 113.81 yen. The WSJ Dollar Index declined 0.1%.

Asian markets fell after American officials barred China Telecom, China's biggest telecom operator, from doing business in the U.S., adding to investor concerns over tensions between the two biggest economies.

Early Thursday, Japan's Nikkei was down 1%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng was down 0.3% and the Shanghai Composite was down 1.1%. U.S. stock futures were up 0.1%.
